![](./figures_images/R_logo.png){#id .class width=auto height=16px} provides a formula interface to linear models via the function `lm` and to generalized linear models via the function `glm`. That is, instead of specifying the matrix $X$ explicitly, it is derived from a formula. This is very convenient, and it allows us to focus on variables instead of how they are encoded as columns in $X.$ It is, however, useful to know precisely how ![](./figures_images/R_logo.png){#id .class width=auto height=16px} interprets the formulas and translates them into matrices.

The matrix $X$ is known as the model matrix in ![](./figures_images/R_logo.png){#id .class width=auto height=16px} terminology. Internally to `lm` or `glm` the function `model.matrix` is used to create the model matrix from the formula and the data. We usually don’t need to call this function, but it is illustrative for understanding exactly how formulas are parsed.

# Sample data
We simulate an example data set to work with.


```{r}
set.seed(04022016)
b <- rnorm(150, 0)
c <- factor(sample(c(rep("A", 50), rep("B", 50), rep("C", 50))))
mu <- (c == "A") + cos(b) + 0.5 * (c == "B") * sin(b)
a <- rnorm(150, mu, 0.5)
```

The left figure below shows a scatter plot of the data. The right figure adds colour coding according to the group as encoded by the `c` variable. The dashed curves are the true means within the three groups.

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)
p1 <- qplot(b, a)
p2 <- qplot(b, a, color = c) + geom_line(aes(y = mu), linetype = 2) +
  theme(legend.position = "top")
grid.arrange(p1, p2, ncol = 2)
```


**Question 1:** Fit a linear regression model to data generated as above with a the response variable and b the predictor. Investigate the residuals. Does the model fit the data?

We build the model
```{r}
abc_data <- tibble(a = a, b = b, c = c)
lm_model01 <- lm(a ~ b, data = abc_data)
```

```{r}
lm_model01_fort <- fortify(lm_model01)
(p_res_fit_01 <- lm_model01_fort %>%
    ggplot(mapping = aes(x = .fitted, y = .stdresid)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth())
(p_res_01 <- lm_model01_fort %>%
    ggplot(aes(.stdresid)) +
    geom_bar())
```


```{r}
lm_model01_fort %>% summary()
```
```{r}
qqq_data <- tibble(a = runif(10^4,0,1), b = runif(10^4, 1, 2), c = runif(10^4, 2, 3))
qqq_data %>% ggplot(aes(a)) + geom_histogram()
```




```{r}
ggplot(data = lm_model01_fort, mapping = aes(.stdresid)) + geom_histogram(bins = 40)
```
